member.name: T:Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.CreateActivityRequest
member.summary:
Container for the parameters to the CreateActivity operation. Creates an activity. An activity is a task that you write in any programming language and host on any machine that has access to AWS Step Functions. Activities must poll Step Functions using the GetActivityTask API action and respond using SendTask* API actions. This function lets Step Functions know the existence of your activity and returns an identifier for use in a state machine and when polling from the activity.
This operation is eventually consistent. The results are best effort and may not reflect very recent updates and changes.
CreateActivity is an idempotent API. Subsequent requests won’t create a duplicate resource if it was already created. CreateActivity's idempotency check is based on the activity name. If a following request has different tags values, Step Functions will ignore these differences and treat it as an idempotent request of the previous. In this case, tags will not be updated, even if they are different.

member.name: P:Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.CreateActivityRequest.Name
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Name.
The name of the activity to create. This name must be unique for your AWS account and region for 90 days. For more information, see Limits Related to State Machine Executions in the AWS Step Functions Developer Guide.
A name must not contain:
white space
brackets < > { } [ ]
wildcard characters ? *
special characters " # % \ ^ | ~ ` $ & , ; : /
control characters (U+0000-001F, U+007F-009F)
To enable logging with CloudWatch Logs, the name should only contain 0-9, A-Z, a-z, - and _.

member.name: P:Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.CreateActivityRequest.Tags
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Tags.
The list of tags to add to a resource.
An array of key-value pairs. For more information, see Using Cost Allocation Tags in the AWS Billing and Cost Management User Guide, and Controlling Access Using IAM Tags.
Tags may only contain Unicode letters, digits, white space, or these symbols: _ . : / = + - @.

member.name: T:Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.CreateActivityResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the CreateActivity operation.

member.name: P:Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.CreateActivityResponse.ActivityArn
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ActivityArn.
The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) that identifies the created activity.

member.name: P:Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.CreateActivityResponse.CreationDate
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property CreationDate.
The date the activity is created.

member.name: T:Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.CreateStateMachineRequest
member.summary:
Container for the parameters to the CreateStateMachine operation. Creates a state machine. A state machine consists of a collection of states that can do work (Task states), determine to which states to transition next (Choice states), stop an execution with an error (Fail states), and so on. State machines are specified using a JSON-based, structured language. For more information, see Amazon States Language in the AWS Step Functions User Guide.
This operation is eventually consistent. The results are best effort and may not reflect very recent updates and changes.
CreateStateMachine is an idempotent API. Subsequent requests won’t create a duplicate resource if it was already created. CreateStateMachine's idempotency check is based on the state machine name, definition, type, LoggingConfiguration and TracingConfiguration. If a following request has a different roleArn or tags, Step Functions will ignore these differences and treat it as an idempotent request of the previous. In this case, roleArn and tags will not be updated, even if they are different.

member.name: P:Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.CreateStateMachineRequest.Definition
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Definition.
The Amazon States Language definition of the state machine. See Amazon States Language.

member.name: P:Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.CreateStateMachineRequest.LoggingConfiguration
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property LoggingConfiguration.
Defines what execution history events are logged and where they are logged.
By default, the level is set to OFF. For more information see Log Levels in the AWS Step Functions User Guide.

member.name: P:Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.CreateStateMachineRequest.Name
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Name.
The name of the state machine.
A name must not contain:
white space
brackets < > { } [ ]
wildcard characters ? *
special characters " # % \ ^ | ~ ` $ & , ; : /
control characters (U+0000-001F, U+007F-009F)
To enable logging with CloudWatch Logs, the name should only contain 0-9, A-Z, a-z, - and _.

member.name: P:Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.CreateStateMachineRequest.RoleArn
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property RoleArn.
The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the IAM role to use for this state machine.

member.name: P:Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.CreateStateMachineRequest.Tags
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Tags.
Tags to be added when creating a state machine.
An array of key-value pairs. For more information, see Using Cost Allocation Tags in the AWS Billing and Cost Management User Guide, and Controlling Access Using IAM Tags.
Tags may only contain Unicode letters, digits, white space, or these symbols: _ . : / = + - @.

member.name: P:Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.CreateStateMachineRequest.TracingConfiguration
member.summary:

Selects whether AWS X-Ray tracing is enabled.

member.name: T:Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.DeleteStateMachineRequest
member.summary:
Container for the parameters to the DeleteStateMachine operation. Deletes a state machine. This is an asynchronous operation: It sets the state machine's status to DELETING and begins the deletion process.
For EXPRESSstate machines, the deletion will happen eventually (usually less than a minute). Running executions may emit logs after DeleteStateMachine API is called.

member.name: T:Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.GetActivityTaskRequest
member.summary:
Container for the parameters to the GetActivityTask operation. Used by workers to retrieve a task (with the specified activity ARN) which has been scheduled for execution by a running state machine. This initiates a long poll, where the service holds the HTTP connection open and responds as soon as a task becomes available (i.e. an execution of a task of this type is needed.) The maximum time the service holds on to the request before responding is 60 seconds. If no task is available within 60 seconds, the poll returns a taskToken with a null string.
Workers should set their client side socket timeout to at least 65 seconds (5 seconds higher than the maximum time the service may hold the poll request).
Polling with GetActivityTask can cause latency in some implementations. See Avoid Latency When Polling for Activity Tasks in the Step Functions Developer Guide.

member.name: P:Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.GetActivityTaskRequest.ActivityArn
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ActivityArn.
The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the activity to retrieve tasks from (assigned when you create the task using CreateActivity.)

member.name: P:Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.GetActivityTaskRequest.WorkerName
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property WorkerName.
You can provide an arbitrary name in order to identify the worker that the task is assigned to. This name is used when it is logged in the execution history.

member.name: T:Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.GetActivityTaskResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the GetActivityTask operation.

member.name: P:Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.GetActivityTaskResponse.Input
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Input.
The string that contains the JSON input data for the task. Length constraints apply to the payload size, and are expressed as bytes in UTF-8 encoding.

member.name: P:Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.GetActivityTaskResponse.TaskToken
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property TaskToken.
A token that identifies the scheduled task. This token must be copied and included in subsequent calls to SendTaskHeartbeat, SendTaskSuccess or SendTaskFailure in order to report the progress or completion of the task.

member.name: T:Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.GetExecutionHistoryRequest
member.summary:
Container for the parameters to the GetExecutionHistory operation. Returns the history of the specified execution as a list of events. By default, the results are returned in ascending order of the timeStamp of the events. Use the reverseOrder parameter to get the latest events first.
If nextToken is returned, there are more results available. The value of nextToken is a unique pagination token for each page. Make the call again using the returned token to retrieve the next page. Keep all other arguments unchanged. Each pagination token expires after 24 hours. Using an expired pagination token will return an HTTP 400 InvalidToken error.
This API action is not supported by EXPRESS state machines.

member.name: P:Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.GetExecutionHistoryRequest.ExecutionArn
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ExecutionArn.
The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the execution.

member.name: P:Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.GetExecutionHistoryRequest.IncludeExecutionData
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property IncludeExecutionData.
You can select whether execution data (input or output of a history event) is returned. The default is true.

member.name: P:Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.GetExecutionHistoryRequest.MaxResults
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property MaxResults.
The maximum number of results that are returned per call. You can use nextToken to obtain further pages of results. The default is 100 and the maximum allowed page size is 1000. A value of 0 uses the default.
This is only an upper limit. The actual number of results returned per call might be fewer than the specified maximum.

member.name: P:Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.GetExecutionHistoryRequest.NextToken
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property NextToken.
If nextToken is returned, there are more results available. The value of nextToken is a unique pagination token for each page. Make the call again using the returned token to retrieve the next page. Keep all other arguments unchanged. Each pagination token expires after 24 hours. Using an expired pagination token will return an HTTP 400 InvalidToken error.

member.name: P:Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.GetExecutionHistoryRequest.ReverseOrder
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ReverseOrder.
Lists events in descending order of their timeStamp.

member.summary: This is the response object from the GetExecutionHistory operation.

The list of events that occurred in the execution.

member.name: P:Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.GetExecutionHistoryResponse.NextToken
member.summary:

If nextToken is returned, there are more results available. The value of nextToken is a unique pagination token for each page. Make the call again using the returned token to retrieve the next page. Keep all other arguments unchanged. Each pagination token expires after 24 hours. Using an expired pagination token will return an HTTP 400 InvalidToken error.

member.summary:

member.name: T:Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.SendTaskFailureResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the SendTaskFailure operation.

member.name: T:Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.SendTaskHeartbeatRequest
member.summary:
Container for the parameters to the SendTaskHeartbeat operation. Used by activity workers and task states using the callback pattern to report to Step Functions that the task represented by the specified taskToken is still making progress. This action resets the Heartbeat clock. The Heartbeat threshold is specified in the state machine's Amazon States Language definition (HeartbeatSeconds). This action does not in itself create an event in the execution history. However, if the task times out, the execution history contains an ActivityTimedOut entry for activities, or a TaskTimedOut entry for for tasks using the job run or callback pattern.
The Timeout of a task, defined in the state machine's Amazon States Language definition, is its maximum allowed duration, regardless of the number of SendTaskHeartbeat requests received. Use HeartbeatSeconds to configure the timeout interval for heartbeats.

member.name: P:Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.SendTaskHeartbeatRequest.TaskToken
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property TaskToken.
The token that represents this task. Task tokens are generated by Step Functions when tasks are assigned to a worker, or in the context object when a workflow enters a task state. See GetActivityTaskOutput$taskToken.

member.name: T:Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.SendTaskHeartbeatResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the SendTaskHeartbeat operation.

member.name: T:Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.SendTaskSuccessRequest
member.summary: Container for the parameters to the SendTaskSuccess operation. Used by activity workers and task states using the callback pattern to report that the task identified by the taskToken completed successfully.

member.name: P:Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.SendTaskSuccessRequest.Output
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Output.
The JSON output of the task. Length constraints apply to the payload size, and are expressed as bytes in UTF-8 encoding.

member.name: P:Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.SendTaskSuccessRequest.TaskToken
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property TaskToken.
The token that represents this task. Task tokens are generated by Step Functions when tasks are assigned to a worker, or in the context object when a workflow enters a task state. See GetActivityTaskOutput$taskToken.

member.name: T:Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.SendTaskSuccessResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the SendTaskSuccess operation.

member.name: T:Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.StartExecutionRequest
member.summary:
Container for the parameters to the StartExecution operation. Starts a state machine execution.
StartExecution is idempotent. If StartExecution is called with the same name and input as a running execution, the call will succeed and return the same response as the original request. If the execution is closed or if the input is different, it will return a 400 ExecutionAlreadyExists error. Names can be reused after 90 days.

member.name: P:Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.StartExecutionRequest.Input
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Input.
The string that contains the JSON input data for the execution, for example:
"input": "{\"first_name\" : \"test\"}"
If you don't include any JSON input data, you still must include the two braces, for example: "input": "{}"
Length constraints apply to the payload size, and are expressed as bytes in UTF-8 encoding.

member.name: P:Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.StartExecutionRequest.Name
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Name.

member.name: T:Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.UpdateStateMachineRequest
member.summary:
Container for the parameters to the UpdateStateMachine operation. Updates an existing state machine by modifying its definition, roleArn, or loggingConfiguration. Running executions will continue to use the previous definition and roleArn. You must include at least one of definition or roleArn or you will receive a MissingRequiredParameter error.
All StartExecution calls within a few seconds will use the updated definition and roleArn. Executions started immediately after calling UpdateStateMachine may use the previous state machine definition and roleArn.

member.name: T:Amazon.StepFunctions.AmazonStepFunctionsClient
member.summary:
Implementation for accessing StepFunctions
AWS Step Functions
AWS Step Functions is a service that lets you coordinate the components of distributed applications and microservices using visual workflows.
You can use Step Functions to build applications from individual components, each of which performs a discrete function, or task, allowing you to scale and change applications quickly. Step Functions provides a console that helps visualize the components of your application as a series of steps. Step Functions automatically triggers and tracks each step, and retries steps when there are errors, so your application executes predictably and in the right order every time. Step Functions logs the state of each step, so you can quickly diagnose and debug any issues.
Step Functions manages operations and underlying infrastructure to ensure your application is available at any scale. You can run tasks on AWS, your own servers, or any system that has access to AWS. You can access and use Step Functions using the console, the AWS SDKs, or an HTTP API. For more information about Step Functions, see the AWS Step Functions Developer Guide .

member.name: P:Amazon.StepFunctions.AmazonStepFunctionsClient.Paginators
member.summary: Paginators for the service

member.name: M:Amazon.StepFunctions.AmazonStepFunctionsClient.#ctor
member.summary:
Constructs AmazonStepFunctionsClient with the credentials loaded from the application's default configuration, and if unsuccessful from the Instance Profile service on an EC2 instance.
Example App.config with credentials set.
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" ?> <configuration> <appSettings> <add key="AWSProfileName" value="AWS Default"/> </appSettings> </configuration>

member.name: M:Amazon.StepFunctions.AmazonStepFunctionsClient.#ctor(Amazon.RegionEndpoint)
member.summary:
Constructs AmazonStepFunctionsClient with the credentials loaded from the application's default configuration, and if unsuccessful from the Instance Profile service on an EC2 instance.
Example App.config with credentials set.
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" ?> <configuration> <appSettings> <add key="AWSProfileName" value="AWS Default"/> </appSettings> </configuration>
member.param: The region to connect.

member.name: M:Amazon.StepFunctions.AmazonStepFunctionsClient.CreateActivity(Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.CreateActivityRequest)
member.summary:
Creates an activity. An activity is a task that you write in any programming language and host on any machine that has access to AWS Step Functions. Activities must poll Step Functions using the GetActivityTask API action and respond using SendTask* API actions. This function lets Step Functions know the existence of your activity and returns an identifier for use in a state machine and when polling from the activity.
This operation is eventually consistent. The results are best effort and may not reflect very recent updates and changes.
CreateActivity is an idempotent API. Subsequent requests won’t create a duplicate resource if it was already created. CreateActivity's idempotency check is based on the activity name. If a following request has different tags values, Step Functions will ignore these differences and treat it as an idempotent request of the previous. In this case, tags will not be updated, even if they are different.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the CreateActivity service method.
member.returns: The response from the CreateActivity service method, as returned by StepFunctions.
member.exception: The maximum number of activities has been reached. Existing activities must be deleted before a new activity can be created.
The provided name is invalid.
You've exceeded the number of tags allowed for a resource. See the Limits Topic in the AWS Step Functions Developer Guide.
member.seealso: REST API Reference for CreateActivity Operation

member.name: M:Amazon.StepFunctions.AmazonStepFunctionsClient.CreateStateMachine(Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.CreateStateMachineRequest)
member.summary:
Creates a state machine. A state machine consists of a collection of states that can do work (Task states), determine to which states to transition next (Choice states), stop an execution with an error (Fail states), and so on. State machines are specified using a JSON-based, structured language. For more information, see Amazon States Language in the AWS Step Functions User Guide.
This operation is eventually consistent. The results are best effort and may not reflect very recent updates and changes.
CreateStateMachine is an idempotent API. Subsequent requests won’t create a duplicate resource if it was already created. CreateStateMachine's idempotency check is based on the state machine name, definition, type, LoggingConfiguration and TracingConfiguration. If a following request has a different roleArn or tags, Step Functions will ignore these differences and treat it as an idempotent request of the previous. In this case, roleArn and tags will not be updated, even if they are different.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the CreateStateMachine service method.
member.returns: The response from the CreateStateMachine service method, as returned by StepFunctions.
member.exception: The provided Amazon Resource Name (ARN) is invalid.
The provided Amazon States Language definition is invalid.
The provided name is invalid.
Your tracingConfiguration key does not match, or enabled has not been set to true or false.
A state machine with the same name but a different definition or role ARN already exists.
The specified state machine is being deleted.
The maximum number of state machines has been reached. Existing state machines must be deleted before a new state machine can be created.
You've exceeded the number of tags allowed for a resource. See the Limits Topic in the AWS Step Functions Developer Guide.
member.seealso: REST API Reference for CreateStateMachine Operation

member.name: M:Amazon.StepFunctions.AmazonStepFunctionsClient.DeleteStateMachine(Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.DeleteStateMachineRequest)
member.summary:
Deletes a state machine. This is an asynchronous operation: It sets the state machine's status to DELETING and begins the deletion process.
For EXPRESSstate machines, the deletion will happen eventually (usually less than a minute). Running executions may emit logs after DeleteStateMachine API is called.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the DeleteStateMachine service method.
member.returns: The response from the DeleteStateMachine service method, as returned by StepFunctions.
member.exception: The provided Amazon Resource Name (ARN) is invalid.
member.seealso: REST API Reference for DeleteStateMachine Operation

member.name: M:Amazon.StepFunctions.AmazonStepFunctionsClient.GetActivityTask(Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.GetActivityTaskRequest)
member.summary:
Used by workers to retrieve a task (with the specified activity ARN) which has been scheduled for execution by a running state machine. This initiates a long poll, where the service holds the HTTP connection open and responds as soon as a task becomes available (i.e. an execution of a task of this type is needed.) The maximum time the service holds on to the request before responding is 60 seconds. If no task is available within 60 seconds, the poll returns a taskToken with a null string.
Workers should set their client side socket timeout to at least 65 seconds (5 seconds higher than the maximum time the service may hold the poll request).
Polling with GetActivityTask can cause latency in some implementations. See Avoid Latency When Polling for Activity Tasks in the Step Functions Developer Guide.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the GetActivityTask service method.
member.returns: The response from the GetActivityTask service method, as returned by StepFunctions.
member.exception: The specified activity does not exist.
The maximum number of workers concurrently polling for activity tasks has been reached.
The provided Amazon Resource Name (ARN) is invalid.
member.seealso: REST API Reference for GetActivityTask Operation

member.name: M:Amazon.StepFunctions.AmazonStepFunctionsClient.GetExecutionHistory(Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.GetExecutionHistoryRequest)
member.summary:
Returns the history of the specified execution as a list of events. By default, the results are returned in ascending order of the timeStamp of the events. Use the reverseOrder parameter to get the latest events first.
If nextToken is returned, there are more results available. The value of nextToken is a unique pagination token for each page. Make the call again using the returned token to retrieve the next page. Keep all other arguments unchanged. Each pagination token expires after 24 hours. Using an expired pagination token will return an HTTP 400 InvalidToken error.
This API action is not supported by EXPRESS state machines.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the GetExecutionHistory service method.
member.returns: The response from the GetExecutionHistory service method, as returned by StepFunctions.
member.exception: The specified execution does not exist.
The provided Amazon Resource Name (ARN) is invalid.
The provided token is invalid.
member.seealso: REST API Reference for GetExecutionHistory Operation

member.name: M:Amazon.StepFunctions.AmazonStepFunctionsClient.SendTaskHeartbeat(Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.SendTaskHeartbeatRequest)
member.summary:
Used by activity workers and task states using the callback pattern to report to Step Functions that the task represented by the specified taskToken is still making progress. This action resets the Heartbeat clock. The Heartbeat threshold is specified in the state machine's Amazon States Language definition (HeartbeatSeconds). This action does not in itself create an event in the execution history. However, if the task times out, the execution history contains an ActivityTimedOut entry for activities, or a TaskTimedOut entry for for tasks using the job run or callback pattern.
The Timeout of a task, defined in the state machine's Amazon States Language definition, is its maximum allowed duration, regardless of the number of SendTaskHeartbeat requests received. Use HeartbeatSeconds to configure the timeout interval for heartbeats.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the SendTaskHeartbeat service method.
member.returns: The response from the SendTaskHeartbeat service method, as returned by StepFunctions.
member.exception: The provided token is invalid.
member.seealso: REST API Reference for SendTaskHeartbeat Operation

member.name: M:Amazon.StepFunctions.AmazonStepFunctionsClient.StartExecution(Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.StartExecutionRequest)
member.summary:
Starts a state machine execution.
StartExecution is idempotent. If StartExecution is called with the same name and input as a running execution, the call will succeed and return the same response as the original request. If the execution is closed or if the input is different, it will return a 400 ExecutionAlreadyExists error. Names can be reused after 90 days.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the StartExecution service method.
member.returns: The response from the StartExecution service method, as returned by StepFunctions.
member.exception:
The execution has the same name as another execution (but a different input).
Executions with the same name and input are considered idempotent.
The maximum number of running executions has been reached. Running executions must end or be stopped before a new execution can be started.
The provided Amazon Resource Name (ARN) is invalid.
The provided JSON input data is invalid.
The provided name is invalid.
The specified state machine is being deleted.
The specified state machine does not exist.

member.name: T:Amazon.StepFunctions.IAmazonStepFunctions
member.summary:
Interface for accessing StepFunctions
AWS Step Functions
AWS Step Functions is a service that lets you coordinate the components of distributed applications and microservices using visual workflows.
You can use Step Functions to build applications from individual components, each of which performs a discrete function, or task, allowing you to scale and change applications quickly. Step Functions provides a console that helps visualize the components of your application as a series of steps. Step Functions automatically triggers and tracks each step, and retries steps when there are errors, so your application executes predictably and in the right order every time. Step Functions logs the state of each step, so you can quickly diagnose and debug any issues.
Step Functions manages operations and underlying infrastructure to ensure your application is available at any scale. You can run tasks on AWS, your own servers, or any system that has access to AWS. You can access and use Step Functions using the console, the AWS SDKs, or an HTTP API. For more information about Step Functions, see the AWS Step Functions Developer Guide .

member.name: M:Amazon.StepFunctions.IAmazonStepFunctions.CreateActivity(Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.CreateActivityRequest)
member.summary:
Creates an activity. An activity is a task that you write in any programming language and host on any machine that has access to AWS Step Functions. Activities must poll Step Functions using the GetActivityTask API action and respond using SendTask* API actions. This function lets Step Functions know the existence of your activity and returns an identifier for use in a state machine and when polling from the activity.
This operation is eventually consistent. The results are best effort and may not reflect very recent updates and changes.
CreateActivity is an idempotent API. Subsequent requests won’t create a duplicate resource if it was already created. CreateActivity's idempotency check is based on the activity name. If a following request has different tags values, Step Functions will ignore these differences and treat it as an idempotent request of the previous. In this case, tags will not be updated, even if they are different.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the CreateActivity service method.
member.returns: The response from the CreateActivity service method, as returned by StepFunctions.
member.exception: The maximum number of activities has been reached. Existing activities must be deleted before a new activity can be created.
The provided name is invalid.
You've exceeded the number of tags allowed for a resource. See the Limits Topic in the AWS Step Functions Developer Guide.
member.seealso: REST API Reference for CreateActivity Operation

member.name: M:Amazon.StepFunctions.IAmazonStepFunctions.CreateStateMachine(Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.CreateStateMachineRequest)
member.summary:
Creates a state machine. A state machine consists of a collection of states that can do work (Task states), determine to which states to transition next (Choice states), stop an execution with an error (Fail states), and so on. State machines are specified using a JSON-based, structured language. For more information, see Amazon States Language in the AWS Step Functions User Guide.
This operation is eventually consistent. The results are best effort and may not reflect very recent updates and changes.
CreateStateMachine is an idempotent API. Subsequent requests won’t create a duplicate resource if it was already created. CreateStateMachine's idempotency check is based on the state machine name, definition, type, LoggingConfiguration and TracingConfiguration. If a following request has a different roleArn or tags, Step Functions will ignore these differences and treat it as an idempotent request of the previous. In this case, roleArn and tags will not be updated, even if they are different.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the CreateStateMachine service method.
member.returns: The response from the CreateStateMachine service method, as returned by StepFunctions.
member.exception: The provided Amazon Resource Name (ARN) is invalid.
The provided Amazon States Language definition is invalid.
The provided name is invalid.
Your tracingConfiguration key does not match, or enabled has not been set to true or false.
A state machine with the same name but a different definition or role ARN already exists.
The specified state machine is being deleted.
The maximum number of state machines has been reached. Existing state machines must be deleted before a new state machine can be created.
You've exceeded the number of tags allowed for a resource. See the Limits Topic in the AWS Step Functions Developer Guide.

member.name: M:Amazon.StepFunctions.IAmazonStepFunctions.GetActivityTask(Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.GetActivityTaskRequest)
member.summary:
Used by workers to retrieve a task (with the specified activity ARN) which has been scheduled for execution by a running state machine. This initiates a long poll, where the service holds the HTTP connection open and responds as soon as a task becomes available (i.e. an execution of a task of this type is needed.) The maximum time the service holds on to the request before responding is 60 seconds. If no task is available within 60 seconds, the poll returns a taskToken with a null string.
Workers should set their client side socket timeout to at least 65 seconds (5 seconds higher than the maximum time the service may hold the poll request).
Polling with GetActivityTask can cause latency in some implementations. See Avoid Latency When Polling for Activity Tasks in the Step Functions Developer Guide.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the GetActivityTask service method.
member.returns: The response from the GetActivityTask service method, as returned by StepFunctions.
member.exception: The specified activity does not exist.
The maximum number of workers concurrently polling for activity tasks has been reached.
The provided Amazon Resource Name (ARN) is invalid.

member.name: M:Amazon.StepFunctions.IAmazonStepFunctions.GetActivityTaskAsync(Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.GetActivityTaskRequest,System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary:
Used by workers to retrieve a task (with the specified activity ARN) which has been scheduled for execution by a running state machine. This initiates a long poll, where the service holds the HTTP connection open and responds as soon as a task becomes available (i.e. an execution of a task of this type is needed.) The maximum time the service holds on to the request before responding is 60 seconds. If no task is available within 60 seconds, the poll returns a taskToken with a null string.
Workers should set their client side socket timeout to at least 65 seconds (5 seconds higher than the maximum time the service may hold the poll request).
Polling with GetActivityTask can cause latency in some implementations. See Avoid Latency When Polling for Activity Tasks in the Step Functions Developer Guide.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the GetActivityTask service method.
A cancellation token that can be used by other objects or threads to receive notice of cancellation.
member.returns: The response from the GetActivityTask service method, as returned by StepFunctions.
member.exception: The specified activity does not exist.
The maximum number of workers concurrently polling for activity tasks has been reached.
The provided Amazon Resource Name (ARN) is invalid.
member.seealso: REST API Reference for GetActivityTask Operation

member.name: M:Amazon.StepFunctions.IAmazonStepFunctions.GetExecutionHistory(Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.GetExecutionHistoryRequest)
member.summary:
Returns the history of the specified execution as a list of events. By default, the results are returned in ascending order of the timeStamp of the events. Use the reverseOrder parameter to get the latest events first.
If nextToken is returned, there are more results available. The value of nextToken is a unique pagination token for each page. Make the call again using the returned token to retrieve the next page. Keep all other arguments unchanged. Each pagination token expires after 24 hours. Using an expired pagination token will return an HTTP 400 InvalidToken error.
This API action is not supported by EXPRESS state machines.

member.name: M:Amazon.StepFunctions.IAmazonStepFunctions.SendTaskHeartbeat(Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.SendTaskHeartbeatRequest)
member.summary:
Used by activity workers and task states using the callback pattern to report to Step Functions that the task represented by the specified taskToken is still making progress. This action resets the Heartbeat clock. The Heartbeat threshold is specified in the state machine's Amazon States Language definition (HeartbeatSeconds). This action does not in itself create an event in the execution history. However, if the task times out, the execution history contains an ActivityTimedOut entry for activities, or a TaskTimedOut entry for for tasks using the job run or callback pattern.
The Timeout of a task, defined in the state machine's Amazon States Language definition, is its maximum allowed duration, regardless of the number of SendTaskHeartbeat requests received. Use HeartbeatSeconds to configure the timeout interval for heartbeats.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the SendTaskHeartbeat service method.
member.returns: The response from the SendTaskHeartbeat service method, as returned by StepFunctions.
member.exception: The provided token is invalid.
member.seealso: REST API Reference for SendTaskHeartbeat Operation

member.name: M:Amazon.StepFunctions.IAmazonStepFunctions.StartExecution(Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.StartExecutionRequest)
member.summary:
Starts a state machine execution.
StartExecution is idempotent. If StartExecution is called with the same name and input as a running execution, the call will succeed and return the same response as the original request. If the execution is closed or if the input is different, it will return a 400 ExecutionAlreadyExists error. Names can be reused after 90 days.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the StartExecution service method.
member.returns: The response from the StartExecution service method, as returned by StepFunctions.
member.exception:
The execution has the same name as another execution (but a different input).
Executions with the same name and input are considered idempotent.
The maximum number of running executions has been reached. Running executions must end or be stopped before a new execution can be started.
The provided Amazon Resource Name (ARN) is invalid.
The provided JSON input data is invalid.
The provided name is invalid.
The specified state machine is being deleted.
The specified state machine does not exist.
member.seealso: REST API Reference for StartExecution Operation

member.name: M:Amazon.StepFunctions.IAmazonStepFunctions.UpdateStateMachine(Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.UpdateStateMachineRequest)
member.summary:
Updates an existing state machine by modifying its definition, roleArn, or loggingConfiguration. Running executions will continue to use the previous definition and roleArn. You must include at least one of definition or roleArn or you will receive a MissingRequiredParameter error.
All StartExecution calls within a few seconds will use the updated definition and roleArn. Executions started immediately after calling UpdateStateMachine may use the previous state machine definition and roleArn.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the UpdateStateMachine service method.
member.returns: The response from the UpdateStateMachine service method, as returned by StepFunctions.

The specified state machine is being deleted.
The specified state machine does not exist.
